Award.AwardTitle: Learning Theory and Analytics as Guides to Improve Undergraduate STEM Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Undergraduate STEM courses are increasingly using learning management systems to provide extra supports for students and instructors. However, little research has been conducted on how best to structure these systems to provide students with metacognitive and motivational supports that might facilitate learning. The project will conduct three studies that will 1) identify how students use the elements of the learning management system content and how that use relates to student performance outcomes in STEM content; 2) test embedded learning strategy training experiences for students and motivational interventions to examine the affordance for student motivation, behavior, achievement, and completion rates; and 3) test whether a behavior-based early warning system will identify problematic learning behaviors earlier and more accurately than existing systems so that interventions might be targeted to the students particular problems.

Four courses in biology, calculus and two engineering domains within the earliest semesters of study at the undergraduate level will be the context of this study. The researchers and instructors from the departments will collaboratively design the learning environments built around Blackboard, the most common learning management system currently in use. The project will collect large grain data currently available from Blackboard of student performances in the system, medium grain data from a secondary module within Blackboard that aggregates behavior and performance and reports at the student level, and small grain data, logs of each student's transaction with the materials hosted in the course. An experimental design will be employed during the project that randomly assigns students different interventions and specific training supports. Data mining techniques, regression and structural modeling approaches will be used to identify patterns and examine the impacts of the training and motivational supports on student learning outcomes in the specified STEM content areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last five years, our project team has examined (1) how STEM undergraduates' learning process can be better understood by observing the ways they engage with digital content in their early large lecture courses, (2) how the data students generate when learning with digital resources can be used to determine who is likely to perform poorly and require learning support, and (3) whether students benefit from digital advice and training to improve their learning skills. This research was undertaken in three phases.

In the first phase, an educational research team partnered with subject matter experts in science, math, and engineering to select important gateway courses that students often have to retake in order to complete a STEM major. The collaborative team redesigned these courses by developing digital versions of learning resources, and by ensuring students could these resources to engage in productive cognitive strategies (such as self-testing and self-explanation) and metacognitive strategies (such as planning and monitoring their learning and performance). Once courses were enriched, the education team partnered with campus information technology experts to develop a system for observing the "learning events" that are produced when students access digital resources for learning.

In the second phase of the project, the research team developed prediction algorithms using the traces of learning events as predictors of student success in courses. Using machine learning algorithms, the team developed models that could accurately predict whether students were more likely to obtain the target grade required - usually a B or C - to advance in their major, or whether the student was more likely to earn a poorer grade and need to re-enroll in a future semester. The best models in science and math were able to accurately identify > 70% of students who would eventually perform poorly in the course before they took their first major exam. These prediction algorithms afforded the opportunity to test whether providing learning supports to those likely to perform poorly could improve their exam and course performances. 

In the third phase of the project, the education team developed learning resources and tested their effects. The first was a Science of Learning to Learn curriculum that taught learning skills and could be embedded in students' science, math, or engineering course site. These modules focused on cognitive strategies and ways students could regulate their learning strategies, behaviors, and environment. Most students completed them in 2-3 hours at a time of their choosing. Across two studies with science learners and one study with college algebra students, those who completed the Science of Learning to Learn outperformed their peers on the exams that followed, and tended to improve their course performance by a third of a letter grade (e.g. C+ to B-).  The second digital learning support was a peer advice page that provided brief recommendations that aligned to the Science of Learning to Learn curriculum. This resource could be read in just a few minutes by students who were identified as likely to perform poorly by prediction algorithms. In two studies in science and one study in math, students who were provided with digital advice and chose to read it outperformed students who received only a reminder about an upcoming exam.

There is intellectual merit in the development of methods to unobtrusively trace learning in authentic contexts as well as in the systematic testing of interventions to teach skills and provide feedback to learners. The digital traces of student learning events provide an important contribution to the study of students' cognitive engagement in learning, self-regulated learning process, and discipline-based research into math, science, and engineering education. The inclusion of demographic records, motivational surveys, digital traces of cognitive and metacognitive processes, and academic achievement enabled researcher to test assumptiomns ofself-regulated learning in authentic contexts. These data also serve as critical process measures that can explain why learners benefit from digital interventions, and why benefits may differ across subgroups who may differ in their preparedness for undergraduate coursework, the social capital that can support their academic endeavors, or other factors.

This project had broader impact on the university community that hosted the research and those who participated in it. Thousands of students benefitted from the rich, digital resources developed for early STEM courses. Hundreds received feedback on their learning as a result of the prediction learning supports. Hundreds more received learning skills training. Each semester, these numbers grow because these digital resources can be provided at practically zero financial cost to the university or time cost to instructors. The university now broadly adopts these instructional co-design practices and trace data methods through an Office of Learning Analytics. Multiple campus units have also adopted the Science of Learning to Learn as a resource to support undergraduate learning.
